image.altText: A group of people stand around on a street chanting and holding up placards

items.synopsis: Academic, politicial and business leaders have weighed in on the prevalence of "unacceptable" protest tactics, after four activists were outside the family home of Woodside's CEO.

title.children: Activists, leaders condemn Woodside protest tactics as Premier reprimands ABC over coverage

items.synopsis: There are calls for Queensland to follow Victoria's lead, which reduced its shooting deaths with a focus on de-escalation of conflict and avoiding or minimising police use of force.

title.children: Queensland Police shot more people than officers in rest of Australia combined last year

image.altText: a woman holding a small child in the doorway of a burnt out home

items.synopsis: Winter temperatures have neared 40 degrees Celsius in parts of South America, which is up to 20C higher than normal for this time of year and the equivalent of Sydney hitting 35C in the first week of August.

title.children: Mid-winter temperatures in South America rival those of the baking northern hemisphere summer

image.altText: A composite photo of Australian and Chinese flags combined with a grain photo overlaid

items.synopsis: China agrees to drop 80 per cent tariffs on Australian barley, after a long-running and high-profile trade war between the two nations.

title.children: China ditches Australian barley tariffs after long-running trade war

image.altText: Fish fillets on display at market, generic image.

items.synopsis: A study of fish sold in supermarkets and restaurants around Australia finds nearly 12 per cent of seafood is mislabelled, as researchers call for more stringent labelling laws.

title.children: DNA testing shows fishy labelling of popular seafoods rife around Australia

image.altText: Elderly man standing in front of court sliding doors with hand behind his back wearing striped jumper

items.synopsis: Alan Charles Jones walks free from court in Albany despite being convicted of sexually abusing a boy 40 years ago.

title.children: Elderly child sex offender avoids jail over historical offences in country WA

image.altText: Two men and a woman walk outside a court building

items.synopsis: An Adelaide court hears there were three grounds for Warren Tredrea's dismissal, which included reputational damage following "inaccurate" comments made on a local radio station about the COVID-19 vaccine.

title.children: Multiple grounds for Channel Nine sports presenter's dismissal, court hears

image.altText: Megan Krakouer wears a shirt marking the 50th anniversary of the tent embassy

items.synopsis: Perth-based Indigenous activist Megan Krakouer switches camps in the Voice to Parliament referendum debate, saying she will now vote yes despite stridently supporting the no campaign previously.

title.children: 'Really difficult decision': Prominent campaigner against Voice set to vote yes after changing mind

image.altText: A house cordoned off with police tape.

items.synopsis: Judith Ann Venn had "reached the end of the road", when she fed her husband his "favourite" vegetable soup, which was laced with 50 pills of his prescription medication.

title.children: 69yo woman jailed for killing abusive husband with spiked vegetable soup

image.altText: A team of people dressed in red and white walk and wave through a stadium, with a Canadian flag.

items.synopsis: Commonwealth Sport Canada says it understands Victoria's recent decision to walk away from hosting the 2026 event was a "significant factor" behind Alberta's announcement.

title.children: Axing of Victoria's Commonwealth Games 'significant factor' in Canadian province backing out of hosting bid

image.altText: An angry looking seagull is making a very direct approach towards you

items.synopsis: From scarecrows to the Bunnings balcony owl, people have tried many ways to deter pesky birds. Here's why one method is causing quite a fluster.

title.children: Pigeons and gulls having a hoot with a new bird deterrent, but residents have been left squawking

image.altText: Two women walking and smiling next to a large flag displaying the Commonwealth Games Federation logo

items.synopsis: Today's latest news, as it happens.

title.children: Prime minister says date of Voice referendum won't be revealed tomorrow — The latest news with The Loop

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Minister for Trade Don Farrell have welcomed the drop of 80 per cent tarriffs China had on Australian Barely. The sanctions on barely trade will be lifted from tomorrow. "It's the right outcome for Australian producers and Chinese cosumers," Senator Wong says. "It affirms the calm and consistent approach the Albanese government has taken." Senator Farrell says since May 2020, China’s duties on Australian barley have effectively blocked exports to that market, worth about $1 billion. "Our barely growers and exporters will now be able to reenter tariff free the Chinese market it's another very positive step in the full resumption of normal trade between Australia and China," he said. The Trade minister says he's hopeful this is a positive step toward resolving all trade disuptes with China.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Drop of barley tariffs affirms 'calm and consistent' approach government has taken, says Penny Wong

props.alt: A woman in a press room in adelaid with australia and torres strait flags visible. She has short grey hair and red blazer on

children.content: (ABC News)
Foreign Minister Penny Wong and Minister for Trade Don Farrell have welcomed the drop of 80 per cent tarriffs China had on Australian Barely.
The sanctions on barely trade will be lifted from tomorrow.
"It's the right outcome for Australian producers and Chinese cosumers," Senator Wong says.
"It affirms the calm and consistent approach the Albanese government has taken."
Senator Farrell says
since May 2020, China’s duties on Australian barley have effectively blocked exports to that market, worth about $1 billion.

"Our barely growers and exporters will now be able to reenter tariff free the Chinese market it's another very positive step in the full resumption of normal trade between Australia and China," he said.
The Trade minister says he's hopeful this is a positive step toward resolving all trade disuptes with China.

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: Anthony Albanese has told media at the Garma Festival he will not announce the Voice referendum date tomorrow, as previously predicted. "We will announce though a date for the referendum at an appropriate time after consultation as well," he says. "One of the things I will be doing this weekend is speaking with people here as I have around the country respectfully about their view of the day." Alabanese says now is the time for Australia to have a Voice to Parliament. "If not now, when?" he says. "We are the only former colony of Europe that does not recognise that there were inhabitants here before 1788, in our case."
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime Minister confirms date of Voice referendum won't be revealed tomorrow

children.content: Anthony Albanese has told media at the Garma Festival he will not announce the Voice referendum date tomorrow, as previously predicted.
"We will announce though a date for the referendum at an appropriate time after consultation as well," he says.
"One of the things I will be doing this weekend is speaking with people here as I have around the country respectfully about their view of the day."
Alabanese says now is the time for Australia to have a Voice to Parliament.
"If not now, when?" he says.
"We are the only former colony of Europe that does not recognise that there were inhabitants here before 1788, in our case."

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: In an announcement at the Garma Festival, Anthony Albanese has confirmed a commitment of $6.4 million to develop a Garma Institute for tertiary education in North East Arnhem Land. "We know the vision for on-country learning for younger people, from early childhood education to university, is something so important," he says. "We know it works. The local schools are a success. The school attendance rates shows what works for them." Albanese says the institute will ensure people can stay on country and continue study among their community.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Prime Minister confirms tertiary institution in North East Arnhem Land

props.alt: Anthony albanese in a pink shirt fronts the media

children.content: (ABC News)
In an announcement at the Garma Festival, Anthony Albanese has confirmed a commitment of
$6.4 million to develop a Garma Institute for tertiary education
in North East Arnhem Land.
"We know the vision for on-country learning for younger people, from early childhood education to university, is something so important," he says.
"We know it works. The local schools are a success. The school attendance rates shows what works for them."
Albanese says the institute will ensure people can stay on country and continue study among their community.

image.altText: A composite image of brothers Obaid and Shaheryer Khan, wearing suits outside court.

items.synopsis: Two brothers are facing the prospect of jail and deportation from Australia, over their involvement in a counterfeit stamp scam led by their older brother, a court hears.

title.children: Older brother the 'architect' in counterfeit stamp scam, as younger siblings take the fall

image.altText: A person in high-vis follows a search dog in a scrubby outback area.

items.synopsis: A private canine tracking group engaged by the family of Wesley Lockyer says police have been alerted to multiple sites of interest following a four-day search.

title.children: Sites of interest identified in search for missing Pilbara man

image.altText: A young male soldier in uniform is photographed in front of an Australian flag.

items.synopsis: The Townsville Hospital and Health Service says it delivered "appropriate" care to army veteran Steven Angus, who was shot by police shortly after being released from hospital care.

title.children: Townsville Hospital says its care of a veteran, later shot dead by police, left 'no opportunities missed'

image.altText: Gordon has a long grey beard and wears a solemn expression as he looks at the camera

items.synopsis: Child sexual abuse survivors in Western Australia warn the process of seeking justice is failing them, and they hope a parliamentary inquiry will help them have their day in court.

title.children: Gordon Batty was left 'gutted' after being begged to let his 'demons out of the closet'. Now he can tell his story again

image.altText: A court sketch depicts Donald Trump with his trademark coiffed blonde hair, blue suit and red tie, hands folded on a table

items.synopsis: Donald Trump's third indictment marks an extraordinary moment: a former president is fighting charges over his handling of the last election, while campaigning to win the next one.

title.children: Why Donald Trump’s third indictment could prove to be the most damaging

image.altText: A woman taking a selfie

items.synopsis: A 34-year-old woman on bail for her alleged role in a 2021 murder has asked the Supreme Court to send her back to prison because of the "daily battle just trying to find suitable accommodation".

title.children: Woman on bail unable to find housing asks court to send her back to jail, judge agrees

image.altText: Chilling footage shows Tarikjot Singh buying items used to kill former partner

items.synopsis: The CCTV footage shows Tarikjot Singh in the aisles of a Bunnings store, purchasing items before he buried alive his ex-girlfriend Jasmeen Kaur in the Flinders Ranges in March 2021.

title.children: Released footage shows murderer buying cable ties, shovel at Bunnings before abduction of ex-girlfriend

image.altText: A man smiling and leaning on a wooden fence with an elephant in an enclosure in the background.

items.synopsis: The zoo announced that Monarto Safari Park in South Australia had started fundraising to build a new elephant habitat so it could welcome the two Perth animals, Permai and Putra Mas.

title.children: Perth Zoo to undertake 'jumbo exercise' to relocate its last elephants to South Australia

image.altText: Neil Gaughan at a Senate Committee.

items.synopsis: The Australian Federal Police is forced to correct the record and clarify that Opposition Leader Peter Dutton was not briefed on the identity of a man later jailed for bribing Nauru government officials.

title.children: AFP admits Peter Dutton was not specifically briefed on concerns over Nauru businessman

image.altText: A man in police uniform sits at a desk with a small microphone and nameplate in front of him.

items.synopsis: Australian Federal Police Commissioner Reece Kershaw rubbishes suggestions he should have declared a conflict of interest over his friendship with a senior PwC partner with whom he discussed a contract for the consulting firm.

title.children: 'No apologies': AFP commissioner rubbishes claims he should have declared friendship with PwC partner

image.altText: An aerial shot of a large lake of water near a waste water treatment facility.

items.synopsis: A sustainability expert says using recycled water on parks and gardens is essential in WA's climate. But despite handing over almost $12 million for a scheme in regional WA, the state government says its project is still in the design phase.

title.children: Perth drinking water still being used to water regional parks and gardens as water recycling scheme stalls

image.altText: JWST/NIRcam composite image of the Ring Nebula. The images clearly show the main ring, surrounded by a faint halo

items.synopsis: The ethereal new images provide further insight into the life cycle of stars.

title.children: 'A preview of the Sun’s distant future': James Webb telescope captures brilliant new images of dying star

image.altText: A woman dressed up and smiling at the camera.

items.synopsis: The family of Gulgong schoolgirl Michelle Bright who was murdered while walking home from a party 24 years ago, say her killer took away her dreams and tore their family apart.

title.children: 'Instead of celebrating birthdays, we take flowers to the cemetery': Slain teen's family confront 'monster' killer

image.altText: Aerial photo of Groote Eylandt coast line.

items.synopsis: Police say spears, crossbows and machetes have been used in the violence which involved up to 150 people on the island in the Gulf of Carpentaria.

items.synopsis: Garma began as a family gathering and grew to become the largest meeting place of First Nations peoples in the country. Here, the festival's founding family reflects on what the event means to them.

image.altText: Anthony Burke wearing a black polo shirt leaning against a dining table in a well-lit living room

items.synopsis: It's the running joke of home renovation shows — no-one delivers their project on time or on budget. Host of Restoration Australia, and professor of architecture, Anthony Burke warns it's not the only area where would-be renovators and home builders come unstuck.

title.children: Architect professor Anthony Burke has seen all the renovation traps. Here are his tips for avoiding them

image.altText: A man wearing a suit and tie looks down as a microphone is held to his face

items.synopsis: NSW Police seized Mahmoud Abbas laptop and other electronic devices after he was shot outside his home in Greenacre on July 26.

image.altText: Two kids jump in the air in a hug will two others look on across a country football ground

items.synopsis: On King Island, amid a burgeoning luxury golf and tourism market, one of Australia's smallest football leagues is fighting to survive.
